document.masterDocTitle: Redefinition of the millipede subgenus Megaphyllum sensu stricto Verhoeff, 1894 and neotype designation for Megaphyllum austriacum (Latzel, 1884) (Myriapoda: Diplopoda: Julida: Julidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redefinition of the millipede subgenus Megaphyllum sensu stricto Verhoeff, 1894 and neotype designation for Megaphyllum austriacum (Latzel, 1884) (Myriapoda: Diplopoda: Julida: Julidae)

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 14 a – g. Megaphyllum transsylvanicum and Megaphyllum kievenese. M. transsylvanicum syntype male from Transylvania, Romania, ZMB 4380: (14 a) gonopods, posterior view; (14 b) left gonopods, mesal view; (14 c) left promere, meso-posterior view. M. transsylvanicum male from Dobrostan, Bulgaria: (14 d) left opisthomere, antero-lateral view. M. kievense male, after Lohmander (1928): (14 d *) opisthomere. M. transsylvanicum. male from Fruska Gora, Serbia: penis, (14 e) posterior and (14 f) right lateral views. M. transsylvanicum. female from Sinemorec, Bulgaria: (14 g) right vulva, posterior view (setae omitted). Abbreviations: ah: anterior hump, asp: anterior process of the solenomere, ca: central ampulla, ct: connecting tube; pa: posterior ampulla, ph: posterior hump, pp: posterior process, psp: posterior process of the solenomere, rp: rod-like process, P: promere. Scale bars: 0.2 mm.

Abbreviations: ah : anterior hump, asp : anterior process of the solenomere, ca : central ampulla, ct : connecting tube; pa : posterior ampulla, ph : posterior hump, pp : posterior process, psp : posterior process of the solenomere, rp : rod-like process, P : promere. subSubSection.paragraph: Both sexes have two bright dorsal longitudinal bands on a dark grey ground. Body length and height: males: 24.1–44.6mm , 2.2–3.2mm ; females: 35.4–48.8mm , 3.2–3.9mm .

Remarks. This species has a wide distribution range: it can be found in the Balkan Peninsula and in Eastern Europe, from Greece to Ukraine ; from sea level up to 1700 m a.s.l.; in diverse habitats as pastures, forests and even in caves (Tăbăcaru et al. 2004 ).

Some of the examined specimens had unusual body colour: one syntype male from Transylvania, and most male specimens from Moldova were uniformly dark; some other males from Bulgaria and Serbia showed faded, hardly visible dorsal bands. A subspecies called
M. t. transdanubicum
was described by Loksa ( 1962 ). According to literature data (Gebhardt 1964 ; Korsós 1994 ) only this subspecies lives in Hungary though Matic & Ceuca ( 1969 ) reported one male without subspecific designation from Orosháza, far from the subspecies’ known distribution. Freshly collected males from Bátaapáti fit well into the subspecies’ distribution area. Unfortunately we could not find any type material so we could only rely on the original description, according to which
M. t. transdanubicum
differs from the nominotypical subspecies by its slightly brighter body colour; wider promere; slightly curved and apically irregularly toothed posterior process of the opisthomere; the pad-like apex of the solenomere which is covered with small spines; the straight or apically slightly curved long, pointed anterior process of the solenomere; and basically to this latter process there can be found a small, posterior toothed process and an anterior hump. We compared Loksa’s ( 1962 ) original drawings with the individual collected from Bátaapáti, syntypes of the nominotypical subspecies from Sarajevo, Sibiu and Transylvania and non-types collected from different parts of Europe and we found no difference in the above listed characters, thus
M. t. transdanubicum
is not a valid subspecies.

M. t. croaticum (Verhoeff, 1929 ) was described on the basis of one male and four females. The gonopod preparation considered as type in the Zoologische Staatsammlung, München (ZSM) was in poor condition and not suitable for comparison.

4 . The
Megaphyllum unilineatum
— species group
Fig. 1 e

Vulvae ( 15–17g , 20g ) differing from other
Megaphyllum
sensu
stricto
species in numerous features: shape not cylindrical but more or less skull-shaped, i.e. with a posterior projection (see
Figs 15g
and
17g
); bursae apically with a more or less distinct posterior hump (
h )
(see
Figs 16–17g
,
20g
). Central ampulla ( ca ) positioned obliquely inside bursa; connecting tube ( ct ) not spiralled, just rumpled and very thin in relation to the posterior ampulla ( pa ).
